title: Implement sharing API endpoints
description:
## Origin
Moved from jeffreysprompts_premium jeffreysprompts_premium-mwb.

## Task
Implement API endpoints for sharing functionality.

## Endpoints

### POST /api/share
Create share link for content.

Request:
```json
{
  "contentType": "user_prompt",
  "contentId": "uuid",
  "password": "optional",  // Will be hashed
  "expiresIn": 7  // Days, optional
}
```

Response:
```json
{
  "linkCode": "x7KmN2pQ4rYz",
  "url": "https://premium.jeffreysprompts.com/share/x7KmN2pQ4rYz",
  "expiresAt": "2024-01-22T00:00:00Z"
}
```

### GET /api/share/:linkCode
Get shared content (public endpoint, no auth required).

If password protected:
- Returns 401 with { "requiresPassword": true }
- Client must POST with password

### POST /api/share/:linkCode/verify
Verify password for protected share.

Request:
```json
{
  "password": "..."
}
```

Response:
- 200 with content if correct
- 401 if incorrect

### GET /api/share/mine
List user's share links.

Response includes:
- All active share links
- View counts
- Expiration status

### DELETE /api/share/:linkCode
Revoke share link (deactivate, don't delete).

### PUT /api/share/:linkCode
Update share link settings.

Request:
```json
{
  "password": "new-password",  // null to remove
  "expiresAt": "2024-02-01"   // null to remove
}
```

## Public Share Page
Route: /share/[linkCode]

- No auth required to view
- Show content preview
- "Save to Library" button (requires auth + premium)
- "Fork" button to create copy
- Track views in share_link_views

## Link Code Generation
```typescript
function generateLinkCode(): string {
  const chars = 'ABCDEFGHJKLMNPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghjkmnpqrstuvwxyz23456789';
  return Array.from({ length: 12 }, () => 
    chars[Math.floor(Math.random() * chars.length)]
  ).join('');
}
```

title: EPIC: Sharing & Collaboration
description:
## Origin
Moved from jeffreysprompts_premium jeffreysprompts_premium-oam.

## Overview
Sharing enables users to distribute their prompts, packs, and collections with others - either publicly via the Swap Meet or privately via direct links.

## Sharing Modes

### 1. Public Sharing (Swap Meet)
- Make content visible to all premium users
- Appears in community browse/search
- Receives ratings and usage stats
- Builds author reputation

### 2. Private Link Sharing
- Generate unique shareable URL
- Anyone with link can view (no auth required for viewing)
- Track link views/uses
- Revoke link anytime
- Optional: password protection
- Optional: expiration date

### 3. Team/Workspace Sharing (V2)
- Share with specific team members
- Workspace-level shared library
- Role-based permissions (view/edit/admin)
- Activity feed for shared content

## Key Features

### Share Dialog
- Choose sharing mode
- Generate/copy share link
- Set link options (password, expiry)
- Preview shared view
- Social share buttons (Twitter, LinkedIn)

### Manage Shared Content
- My Shared Items dashboard
- View share statistics
- Edit sharing settings
- Revoke access
- See who accessed (for team shares)

### Receive Shared Content
- View shared content via link
- Save to own library (if premium)
- Fork/duplicate to own account
- Rate and review (if public)

### Share Targets
- Individual prompts
- Collections
- Prompt packs
- Skills

## Database Schema
- share_links (id, user_id, content_type, content_id, link_code, password_hash, expires_at, created_at)
- share_link_views (link_id, viewer_id, viewed_at, ip_hash)
- team_shares (id, content_type, content_id, team_id, permission_level, shared_by, shared_at)

## Security Considerations
- Rate limit link generation
- Obfuscated link codes (not sequential)
- Optional password protection
- View logging for audit
- DMCA/abuse reporting for public shares

title: EPIC: CLI Authentication & Premium Integration
description:
## Overview
Add optional authentication to the `jfp` CLI tool, allowing users to seamlessly access their premium account data including custom prompts, collections, saved/bookmarked prompts, and notes.

## Why This Matters
The CLI is the primary interface for power users and AI agents. By adding authentication:
- Premium users get their full library in the CLI
- Users can access their collections and saved prompts
- The "swap meet" community prompts become available
- Notes and annotations sync across devices
- Search spans all content (public + personal)

## Design Principles

### 1. Transparent for Non-Users
- All existing functionality works WITHOUT login
- No nag screens, no forced auth, no degraded experience
- Login is purely additive - it unlocks MORE, never restricts
- Clear, honest messaging about what premium provides

### 2. Works Everywhere
- Local machines: Browser-based OAuth with auto-callback
- Remote/SSH: Device code flow (6-character code)
- Headless servers: Same device code flow
- CI/CD: Token-based auth via environment variable

### 3. Secure & Private
- Tokens stored securely in user's config directory
- Short-lived access tokens with refresh capability
- No passwords stored locally
- Easy revocation via web dashboard

## Authentication Flows

### Flow 1: Local Machine (Default)
```
User runs: jfp login
    ↓
CLI starts local HTTP server on random port (e.g., 19847)
    ↓
CLI opens browser to: https://premium.jeffreysprompts.com/cli/auth?port=19847
    ↓
User completes Google OAuth on premium site
    ↓
Premium site redirects to: http://localhost:19847/callback?token=xxx
    ↓
CLI receives token, stores it, shows success message
    ↓
Local server shuts down
```

### Flow 2: Remote Machine (--remote or auto-detected)
```
User runs: jfp login --remote  (or CLI detects no display)
    ↓
CLI requests device code from: POST /api/cli/device-code
    ↓
API returns: { device_code: "abc123", user_code: "XYZW-1234", verification_url: "..." }
    ↓
CLI shows: "Visit https://premium.jeffreysprompts.com/cli/verify and enter code: XYZW-1234"
    ↓
User visits URL, logs in with Google, enters code
    ↓
Meanwhile, CLI polls: POST /api/cli/device-token with device_code
    ↓
Once user completes, API returns access token
    ↓
CLI stores token, shows success
```

### Flow 3: CI/CD / Programmatic
```
User sets: JFP_TOKEN=xxx in environment
    ↓
CLI detects env var, uses it for all authenticated requests
    ↓
No interactive login needed
```

## New CLI Commands

### `jfp login`
- Initiates authentication flow
- Options: `--remote` (force device code flow)
- Stores credentials in `~/.config/jfp/credentials.json`

### `jfp logout`
- Clears stored credentials
- Optionally revokes token on server

### `jfp whoami`
- Shows current authentication status
- Displays: email, tier, token expiry

### `jfp list --mine`
- Lists only user's custom prompts

### `jfp list --saved`
- Lists user's bookmarked/saved prompts

### `jfp collections`
- Lists user's collections
- `jfp collections <name>` shows prompts in collection

### `jfp notes <prompt-id>`
- Shows notes for a prompt
- `jfp notes <prompt-id> --add "note text"` adds a note

## API Endpoints Needed (Premium Site)

### Auth Endpoints
- `POST /api/cli/device-code` - Initiate device code flow
- `POST /api/cli/device-token` - Exchange device code for token
- `POST /api/cli/token/refresh` - Refresh access token
- `POST /api/cli/token/revoke` - Revoke token (logout)

### Data Endpoints (Authenticated)
- `GET /api/cli/me` - Current user info
- `GET /api/cli/prompts` - All prompts (public + user's)
- `GET /api/cli/prompts/mine` - User's custom prompts only
- `GET /api/cli/prompts/saved` - User's saved/bookmarked prompts
- `GET /api/cli/collections` - User's collections
- `GET /api/cli/collections/:id` - Collection details with prompts
- `GET /api/cli/notes/:promptId` - Notes for a prompt
- `POST /api/cli/notes/:promptId` - Add note to prompt

## Token Format
Using JWT with claims:
- `sub`: User ID
- `email`: User email
- `tier`: Subscription tier (free/premium)
- `exp`: Expiration time
- `iat`: Issued at time

## Credential Storage
Location: `~/.config/jfp/credentials.json`
```json
{
  "access_token": "eyJ...",
  "refresh_token": "xxx",
  "expires_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "email": "user@example.com",
  "tier": "premium"
}
```

## Success Criteria
- `jfp login` works on local machines with browser
- `jfp login --remote` works on headless/SSH machines
- Authenticated users see their prompts in `jfp list`
- `jfp search` finds results in personal prompts
- Token refresh happens automatically
- Logout clears all credentials
- Non-authenticated users have identical experience to before
close_reason: All CLI Authentication & Premium Integration features implemented: login (browser + device code), logout, whoami, save, notes, collections, list --mine/--saved, search --mine/--saved/--all/--local. 277 tests passing.

## Database Schema
```typescript
export const userFollows = pgTable('user_follows', {
  id: uuid('id').primaryKey().defaultRandom(),
  followerId: uuid('follower_id').references(() => userProfiles.id).notNull(),
  followeeId: uuid('followee_id').references(() => userProfiles.id).notNull(),
  createdAt: timestamp('created_at').defaultNow(),
}, (table) => [
  unique('uq_follow').on(table.followerId, table.followeeId),
  index('idx_follows_follower').on(table.followerId),
  index('idx_follows_followee').on(table.followeeId),
]);

export const activityFeed = pgTable('activity_feed', {
  id: uuid('id').primaryKey().defaultRandom(),
  userId: uuid('user_id').references(() => userProfiles.id).notNull(), // Feed owner
  actorId: uuid('actor_id').references(() => userProfiles.id).notNull(), // Who did it
  
  activityType: text('activity_type').notNull(), // new_prompt, new_collection, etc.
  resourceType: text('resource_type'),
  resourceId: uuid('resource_id'),
  
  seen: boolean('seen').default(false),

title: Implement tokenizer (search/tokenize.ts)
description:
**Details:**
- `tokenize(text)` splits text into searchable tokens
- Lowercase normalization
- Punctuation removal (preserve hyphens in compound words)
- Stopword filtering (the, a, an, is, are, etc.)
- Optional stemming (simple suffix stripping)
- Unicode normalization (NFD→NFC)

**Implementation:**
```typescript
export function tokenize(text: string): string[] {
  return text
    .toLowerCase()
    .normalize('NFD')
    .replace(/[^\w\s-]/g, ' ')
    .split(/\s+/)
    .filter(token => token.length > 1 && !STOPWORDS.has(token));
}
```

**Stopwords:** Common English stopwords (50-100 words)

**Used By:** BM25 search, synonym expansion

**Reasoning:** Consistent tokenization is foundational for search quality. Must be fast (run on every keystroke in SpotlightSearch) and deterministic.

export const viewHistory = pgTable('view_history', {
  id: uuid('id').primaryKey().defaultRandom(),
  userId: uuid('user_id').references(() => userProfiles.id).notNull(),

}, (table) => [
  index('idx_history_user').on(table.userId),
  index('idx_history_resource').on(table.resourceType, table.resourceId),
  index('idx_history_time').on(table.viewedAt),
]);

```typescript
async function trackView(userId: string, resource: ViewResource) {
  // Dedupe rapid views (ignore if viewed in last 5 min)
  const recent = await getRecentView(userId, resource.id);
  if (recent && isRecent(recent.viewedAt, 5 * 60 * 1000)) {
    return; // Skip duplicate
  }
  
  await db.insert(viewHistory).values({
    userId,
    resourceType: resource.type,
    resourceId: resource.id,
    source: resource.source,
  });
}
```

### Get History
```typescript
async function getRecentlyViewed(userId: string, limit = 10) {
  return db.select()
    .from(viewHistory)
    .where(eq(viewHistory.userId, userId))
    .orderBy(desc(viewHistory.viewedAt))
    .limit(limit);
}
```

title: Add fade transitions when filter results change
description:
# Task: Add Fade Transitions for Filter Changes

## Context
When users apply or remove filters, the PromptGrid results snap instantly. This feels abrupt compared to the smooth card entrance animations. Stripe/Linear use subtle crossfades for content changes.

## Current Behavior
1. User clicks category filter
2. Results instantly swap (jarring)
3. New cards animate in (but old ones just disappear)

## Proposed Behavior
1. User clicks category filter
2. Current results fade out slightly (100ms)
3. New results fade in with staggered animation
4. Smooth transition feels intentional

## Implementation

### Option A: Layout Animation (Recommended)
Use Framer Motion's layout animation on the grid:

```tsx
// PromptGrid.tsx
<motion.div 
  className="grid gap-6 sm:grid-cols-2 lg:grid-cols-3 xl:grid-cols-4"
  layout
>
  <AnimatePresence mode="popLayout">
    {prompts.map((prompt, index) => (
      <motion.div
        key={prompt.id}
        layout
        initial={{ opacity: 0, scale: 0.95 }}
        animate={{ opacity: 1, scale: 1 }}
        exit={{ opacity: 0, scale: 0.95 }}
        transition={{ 
          duration: 0.2,
          delay: Math.min(index * 0.03, 0.15) // Cap delay at 150ms
        }}
      >
        <PromptCard prompt={prompt} index={index} ... />
      </motion.div>
    ))}
  </AnimatePresence>
</motion.div>
```

### Option B: Simple Fade Wrapper
Wrap the entire grid in a fade container that triggers on filter change:

```tsx
// page.tsx
const [isTransitioning, setIsTransitioning] = useState(false);
const prevFilters = useRef(filters);

useEffect(() => {
  if (JSON.stringify(prevFilters.current) !== JSON.stringify(filters)) {
    setIsTransitioning(true);
    setTimeout(() => setIsTransitioning(false), 100);
    prevFilters.current = filters;
  }
}, [filters]);

<motion.div
  animate={{ opacity: isTransitioning ? 0.5 : 1 }}
  transition={{ duration: 0.1 }}
>
  <PromptGrid prompts={filteredPrompts} ... />
</motion.div>
```

### Option C: CSS-Only Transition
Add CSS transition to the grid container:

```css
.prompt-grid {
  transition: opacity 0.15s ease-out;
}

.prompt-grid.transitioning {
  opacity: 0.5;
}
```

## Recommended Approach
**Option A** is best for Stripe-level polish because:
- Individual card animations look premium
- Layout animation handles position changes
- AnimatePresence properly exits old cards
- Staggered delay creates cascade effect

## Design Rationale
- Transitions acknowledge user action
- Fade suggests "content is changing"
- Stagger creates sense of order
- Fast durations (< 200ms) feel responsive

## Testing
1. Apply category filter - cards fade smoothly
2. Remove filter - cards fade back
3. Add tag filter - subset fades in
4. Clear all filters - full set reappears smoothly
5. Rapid filter changes - no janky behavior
6. Reduced motion - instant (no animation)

## Performance Considerations
- layout animations can be expensive with many items
- Cap stagger delay to prevent long waits
- Use will-change: transform on cards if needed
- Test on lower-end devices

## Files Modified
- apps/web/src/components/PromptGrid.tsx
- Possibly apps/web/src/app/page.tsx

## Dependencies
- Framer Motion (already included)
- PromptCard already has entrance animation (coordinate)
- Respects prefers-reduced-motion

# Epic: Accessibility Improvements

## Background & Problem Statement

While the UI overhaul addressed some accessibility issues (adding aria-labels to PromptCard copy button and Hero search input), a comprehensive audit revealed additional gaps that affect screen reader users and keyboard-only navigation.

#### 1. Missing ARIA Labels
- **page.tsx**: "Clear all filters" button has no aria-label
- **SpotlightSearch**: Category pills missing aria-pressed state
- **BasketSidebar**: Remove buttons lack descriptive aria-labels

#### 2. Keyboard Navigation Gaps
- **SwipeablePromptCard**: Swipe actions have no keyboard alternative
- Long-press menu has no keyboard trigger
- Double-tap has no keyboard equivalent

#### 3. Focus Management
- Modal focus trap may not be complete
- SpotlightSearch focus returns correctly, but verify
- Basket sidebar focus management on open/close

#### 4. Screen Reader Experience
- Filter state not announced when changed
- Basket count changes not announced
- Loading states not announced

## WCAG 2.1 AA Compliance Goals
- [ ] All interactive elements have accessible names
- [ ] All custom controls have appropriate roles
- [ ] Focus is visible and managed correctly
- [ ] Dynamic content changes are announced
- [ ] Keyboard navigation is complete

## Success Criteria
- [ ] VoiceOver (macOS/iOS) can navigate all features
- [ ] NVDA/JAWS can navigate all features
- [ ] Keyboard-only users can access all functionality
- [ ] Lighthouse accessibility score > 95

## Design Principles
- Accessibility is not optional
- Screen reader experience should match visual experience
- Keyboard should be first-class input method
- Test with actual assistive technology

## Dependencies
- Should be done alongside other improvements
- Some changes affect the same code as color/UX fixes
- Can be parallelized with other work

title: Typography Standardization: Eliminate arbitrary text sizes
description:
# Epic: Typography Standardization

## Background & Problem Statement

The UI overhaul established a 5-size typography scale in globals.css:
- text-xs (12px)
- text-sm (14px)
- text-base (16px)
- text-lg (18px)
- text-xl+ (headings)

However, several components still use arbitrary values like \`text-[11px]\` and \`text-[10px]\`, which:
1. Break the design system's rhythm
2. Are harder to maintain
3. Create subtle inconsistencies between similar elements

## Files Affected
1. PromptDetailModal.tsx - 3 instances of text-[11px]
2. SpotlightSearch.tsx - 1 instance of text-[11px], 3 instances of text-[10px]

## The Fix
Replace all arbitrary text sizes with the nearest standard size:
- \`text-[11px]\` → \`text-xs\` (12px, +1px - negligible visual difference)
- \`text-[10px]\` → \`text-xs\` (12px, +2px - slightly larger but more readable)

## Implementation Note
**Typography fixes are included in the color fix tasks:**
- g0oe (PromptDetailModal) - includes "Also Fix Typography" section
- usn5 (SpotlightSearch) - includes "Also Fix Typography" section

This keeps related changes together (same lines of code) and reduces PR churn.

## Design Rationale
- 10-11px text is often too small for comfortable reading
- The extra 1-2px improves accessibility without breaking layouts
- Consistency trumps pixel-perfect sizing for this use case

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Zero instances of \`text-[Npx]\` in component files
- [ ] All text uses standard Tailwind classes
- [ ] No layout shifts from size changes
- [ ] Text remains readable at all sizes

## Validation
The color validation tests (tzmc) include a typography consistency check that will verify no arbitrary text sizes remain.

## Dependencies
- Typography fixes are bundled into g0oe and usn5 tasks
- tzmc validates the result

## Estimated Scope

## Origin
Mirror from jeffreysprompts_premium jeffreysprompts_premium-vxw. Keep both repos in sync.

## Task
Configure security headers and Content Security Policy for production.

## Security Headers

### Required Headers
```typescript
// next.config.ts headers
{
  'X-DNS-Prefetch-Control': 'on',
  'Strict-Transport-Security': 'max-age=63072000; includeSubDomains; preload',
  'X-Frame-Options': 'SAMEORIGIN',
  'X-Content-Type-Options': 'nosniff',
  'Referrer-Policy': 'strict-origin-when-cross-origin',
  'Permissions-Policy': 'camera=(), microphone=(), geolocation=()',
}
```

### Content Security Policy
```
default-src 'self';
script-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline' 'unsafe-eval' https://js.stripe.com;
style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline';
img-src 'self' data: https: blob:;
font-src 'self' data:;
connect-src 'self' https://*.supabase.co https://api.stripe.com;
frame-src https://js.stripe.com https://hooks.stripe.com;
object-src 'none';
base-uri 'self';
form-action 'self';
```

### CSP Nonce (for inline scripts)
- Generate nonce per request
- Apply to script tags
- Pass via middleware

## Implementation

### next.config.ts
- Add security headers
- Configure CSP

### proxy.ts (middleware)
- Generate CSP nonce
- Add to response headers

### Verification
- Security headers scan
- CSP validation
- No console errors

## Files to Modify
- next.config.ts
- src/proxy.ts

## Success Criteria
- All security headers present
- CSP blocks unauthorized sources
- No functionality broken
- A+ on securityheaders.com

## CSP Hardening Notes
- Prefer nonce-based script-src; avoid unsafe-inline/unsafe-eval wherever possible.
- Add frame-ancestors 'self' to prevent clickjacking (keeps Stripe frames on frame-src only).
- Add report-to or report-uri for CSP violation reporting (route to Sentry or log endpoint).
- Include upgrade-insecure-requests and block-all-mixed-content in production.
- Validate Supabase, Stripe, and asset domains explicitly (no wildcard unless needed).

## Why This Matters
- Handle violations consistently
- Progressive discipline
- Document actions
- Enable reinstatement

## Discipline Levels

### 1. Warning
- First offense for minor issues
- No access restriction
- Logged in history
- Educational message

### 2. Temporary Suspension (1-30 days)
- Moderate violations
- Cannot access account
- Content hidden
- Auto-reinstates

### 3. Indefinite Suspension
- Serious violations
- Manual review required
- Appeal possible
- Content preserved

### 4. Permanent Ban
- Severe/repeat violations
- Account deleted
- Content removed
- IP tracked (optional)

## Implementation

### Moderation Actions Table
```typescript
export const moderationActions = pgTable('moderation_actions', {
  id: uuid('id').primaryKey().defaultRandom(),
  
  // Target
  userId: uuid('user_id').references(() => userProfiles.id).notNull(),

  // Action
  actionType: text('action_type').notNull(), // warning, suspension, ban

  reason: text('reason').notNull(),
  internalNotes: text('internal_notes'),
  
  // Duration (for suspensions)
  startsAt: timestamp('starts_at').defaultNow(),
  endsAt: timestamp('ends_at'),
  
  // Tracking

async function checkUserStatus(userId: string): Promise<UserStatus> {
  const activeActions = await db.select()
    .from(moderationActions)
    .where(and(

      isNull(moderationActions.reversedAt),
      or(
        isNull(moderationActions.endsAt),
        gt(moderationActions.endsAt, new Date())
      )
    ))
    .orderBy(desc(moderationActions.severity));
  
  if (activeActions.length === 0) return { status: 'active' };
  
  const mostSevere = activeActions[0];
  return {

    reason: mostSevere.reason,
    endsAt: mostSevere.endsAt,

}

## Task
Create process for handling DMCA takedown requests and copyright claims.

## Why This Matters
- Legal compliance (DMCA Safe Harbor)
- Protect platform from liability
- Support content creators
- Handle disputes fairly

## Process

### 1. DMCA Takedown Request
- Public submission form
- Required information (claimant, content, signature)
- Notification to content owner
- 48-hour review period

### 2. Counter-Notice
- Allow content owner to dispute
- Required counter-notice format
- 10-14 day waiting period
- Restore if no lawsuit filed

### 3. Repeat Infringers
- Track strike count
- 3 strikes policy
- Account termination
- Appeals process

## Submission Form Fields
```typescript
interface DMCARequest {
  // Claimant info
  claimantName: string;
  claimantEmail: string;
  claimantAddress: string;
  
  // Content info
  copyrightedWorkDescription: string;
  copyrightedWorkUrl?: string;
  infringingContentUrl: string;
  
  // Legal attestations
  goodFaithStatement: boolean;
  accuracyStatement: boolean;
  ownershipStatement: boolean;
  
  // Signature
  signature: string;
  signatureDate: Date;
}
```

## Database
```typescript
export const dmcaRequests = pgTable('dmca_requests', {
  id: uuid('id').primaryKey().defaultRandom(),
  
  // Claimant
  claimantName: text('claimant_name').notNull(),
  claimantEmail: text('claimant_email').notNull(),
  
  // Content

  contentId: uuid('content_id').notNull(),

  // Status

  // Counter-notice
  counterNoticeAt: timestamp('counter_notice_at'),
  counterNoticeContent: text('counter_notice_content'),
  
  // Resolution

});

  expiresAt: timestamp('expires_at'), // Strikes may expire after time
});
```

# Task: Fix Touch Target Sizes

## Context
Apple and Google HIG recommend minimum 44x44px touch targets for comfortable interaction. Several components violate this guideline.

## Specific Violations

### 1. SpotlightSearch Category Pills (lines 517-543)
**Current:** `py-1.5` ≈ 28px height
```tsx
<button className="shrink-0 px-3 py-1.5 rounded-full text-xs font-medium ...">
```

**Fix:** Increase to `py-2.5` for ~40px, or add min-height
```tsx
<button className="shrink-0 px-3 py-2.5 min-h-[44px] rounded-full text-sm font-medium ...">
```

### 2. BasketSidebar Remove Button (lines 223-229)
**Current:** `h-7 w-7` = 28px
```tsx
<Button variant="ghost" size="icon" className="h-7 w-7 shrink-0">
  <X className="h-3 w-3" />
</Button>
```

**Fix:** Increase to `h-9 w-9` = 36px (or h-11 w-11 = 44px)
```tsx
<Button 
  variant="ghost" 
  size="icon" 
  className="h-9 w-9 shrink-0 -mr-2" // Negative margin to maintain visual spacing
  aria-label={`Remove ${prompt.title} from basket`}
>
  <X className="h-4 w-4" />
</Button>
```

### 3. SpotlightSearch Close Button (mobile, lines 497-504)

<button className="shrink-0 size-8 rounded-lg ...">

}

description:
## Origin

## Task
Create algorithm for surfacing trending and recommended content.

## Why This Matters
- Help users discover great content
- Reward quality contributors
- Drive engagement
- Fresh content on homepage

## Trending Signals

### Engagement Metrics
- Views (weighted by recency)
- Saves/bookmarks
- Uses (copied/exported)
- Shares
- Ratings (weighted average)

### Quality Signals
- Creator reputation
- Content completeness
- Has description
- Has examples
- Tagged appropriately

### Freshness
- Recent content boosted
- Decay over time
- Evergreen content exceptions

## Algorithm

### Trending Score
```typescript
function calculateTrendingScore(prompt: Prompt, window: Duration): number {
  const viewScore = weightedViews(prompt.views, window) * 1.0;
  const saveScore = prompt.saveCount * 3.0;
  const useScore = prompt.useCount * 2.0;
  const shareScore = prompt.shareCount * 2.5;
  const ratingScore = (prompt.avgRating - 3) * prompt.ratingCount * 0.5;
  
  const engagementScore = viewScore + saveScore + useScore + shareScore + ratingScore;
  
  // Quality multiplier (0.5 - 1.5)
  const qualityMultiplier = calculateQualityScore(prompt);
  
  // Freshness decay
  const freshnessDecay = Math.pow(0.95, daysSinceCreated(prompt));
  
  return engagementScore * qualityMultiplier * freshnessDecay;
}
```

### Personalized Recommendations
- Based on user's saved content
- Based on viewing history
